page.lettertext:
fol.255r
May it please your good L. Where I writ unto you laste
e
7
th
of this moneth, that
e
States
had resolved to do somewhat in
Britaine, it was a matter so concluded in their secret assembly, and
not imparted as yet to
e
Councel of state
, for I had knoledge of
their purpose by meanes of a friend. Howbeit
M
r
Barnevelt
by appointment of
e States, came yesterday unto me and declared
their intention: wherof in their behalf he was willed to request mee
to advertise her
Ma
ty
.
For though they purpose of themselves
to send a messenger unto her, yet their meaning is first to sounde
her Hig
nes
good liking, by some motion in general, to induce the
Provinces therby to like
e better of their doing. The effect
of their dessigne was delivered thus unto mee, That forasmuche
as
e Spaniard hath taken a strong footing in divers places of
Brittaine, w
th
intention, as it seemeth, to possesse that contrey
to themselves, w
ch
will presently bring
e traffique, aswel of
the Englishe nation, as of
e people of thes Provinces, and
e state
of bothe contreys into infinite perils: in that respect they thought
it needfull, that they should be mightely assailed, both by
land and by sea, and all upon
e suddaine, w
th
out giving them
the leisure to multiplie further, or to fortifie their places./
For good perfourmance wherof, they wil be willing for their
abilitie, to extend it to
e uttermoste. They will arme for
their part
10 or 12 good ships, and every ship of 200 tonnes
w
th
provision convenient for so many monethes, as
e service shall
require. They will also take order for defrayeng
e charges
of 2000 souldiers, and send 8 or 10 cannons w
th
powder and
bullet for 4000 shot, But all w
th
condition that her Ma
ty
will
assent to double their proportion, or at least to do asmuch and
half asmuch againe. And likewise of
e
King,
they doo
require
e furnishing of 2000 horse, 5 or 6000 foote, and
8 cannons, w
th
a ratable quantity of powder and bullet.
W
th
this conjunction of common forces, they think there is appa-
rence to subdue
e ennemie very quickly. But unles her
Ma
ty
and
e King will come to
t
proportion, w
ch
they have sett
downe, they are wholy out of hope of doing anye goode,
fol.255v
and they think that the Provinces will bee moved to do nothing.
For the place, w
ch
they desire should be first of all attempted
is
Blavet,
w
ch
they take to bee so strong that it cannot bee
recovered, but by spetiall force and if
e Spaniard
bee
suffered to settell there at will, they can want no opportunity
to stop
e course of all traffique; and still have meanes
to bee relieved. For they saie that
Donkerk
is sufficient
to send some 30 ships to sea. For the time of this service
they have assigned it in Julj, having no comodious meanes to
undertake it any sooner. And for the raising of those troupes
w
ch
they wold employ, they rest as yet uncertaine, from whence
they may drawe them, whether they shall send them from hence
or take anye of those w
ch
are in
Fra nce
alredie, or levie
some in
England,
if her Ma
ty
be so contented. But howsoever,
they wil take sufficient order, that their offer in that behalf
shal be
fectly perfourmed. Yo
r
L. will vouchesafe to
acquaint her Ma
ty
with this motion, and to signifie w
th
e
soonest, for so they do entreat, what answere I shall make.
April
22 1592.
